titleStmt.title: CW 110
titleStmt.author: Carmichael, Alexander Archibald (1832‐1912)
titleStmt.sponsor: Edinburgh University Library and the Department of Scottish and Celtic Studies

interpretation.p: All digital surrogates of the original source are linked with the markup textfile.
All Gaelic (and some English) texts have an English summary, keywords, and, where applicable, a taxonomic reference.
For some Gaelic (and English) texts a bibliographic reference(s) will be provided to printed texts.

correction.p: Errors from the original source transcription have been kept to a minimum by employing a double re‐keying method when typed out. In addition, all re‐keyed texts have been proof‐read by the text editors.

A guiding principle of the Alexander Carmichael notebooks markup procedure is to approximate the original document as closely as possible, so that the character of Carmichael's transcriptions is preserved along with its content. XML (eXtensible Markup Language), with its capacity to convey emendations such as deletions (crossed out) and supralinear additions and so forth, can digitally reproduce an authentic version which reflects the source documents.
Where authorial changes, e.g. substitution, have occurred in the text then this has been annotated.
All words have been retained as written in the source text even when there are apparent errors in either spelling or when there has been either an omission in punctuation or grammar.

In such cases missing words or letters have not been supplied. Quotation marks and other missing grammatical marks have not been supplied. Where there are gaps in the text usually because the word was inaudible (some background noise, perhaps) or where the transcriber could not make out what was being said in the act of transcription (perhaps the speaker was inarticulate or mumbling or for whatever reason) then these have been tagged, though not explained; where a word is now difficult, illegible or just unclear, then this has also been tagged.
All such changes have been annotated in accordance with TEI 5 procedures.

normalization.p: No normalization of the words such as changing the source text to conform with current Gaelic orthographic conventions has been undertaken. The texts are as given with only minor editorial changes. in order to preserve the integrity of the original texts.

quotation.p: All opening quotation marks, hyphens, dashes, apostrophes, periods, colons, etc. have been retained in the source text and have been encoded in accodance with ISO entity references, etc.
All double marks have been processed using straight quotation marks, that is, ". All single quotation marks have been rendered using apostrophe.

hyphenation.p: End‐of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.

segmentation.p: Folio numbers have been added in pencil at the top of each notebook page are retained using the pb (pagebreak) element together with the n attribute for the page number and the ed attribute to specify the edition.
When an tale‐text or song which, more often than not, fills more than one page, it is segmented with page break.

A reference system has been built up using the identifiers of the following text units: text, division, paragraph. Each nested division has an identifier which is built up by successively adding to the identifier of the text. Each paragraph has an identifier which adds yet another layer to the immediately superordinate identifier.

langUsage.language: Approximately 95% of the texts are Scottish Gaelic, 2.5% of the texts are in Irish Gaelic and the remainder being roughly divided between English and Scots.

change.item: Added new Encoding and Profile Descriptions

lg.l: C. Am fac thu each seachad an seo?
F. Chunnaic.
C. Saoil am beir mismise air?
F. Ma ruitheas tu gu luath
Lair a bhreabadh
As na creagan
MisMise air a muin
'S ise na ruith
Lan an duirn
De chaorann dearga
Air muin a h-earbaill
'S ì na ruith

div.p: Carmina, Caorann page

From W.William M.MacLeod Thorburn (of Skye)
Wellgate, Dundee
Obtained by me from William Alexander Craigie, Oxford
of the Oxford Dictionary. A.Alexander C.Carmichael 9th April 1901

Cure – A crofter woman in Cnoc
an torrain was {winnowingfasgnadh bere on the
knoll when a grain of bere
went in her ear. Her friend tried to extract
the grain of bere from the womans
ear but failed. Part of the awn was still
attached to the spiligean and after its
manner its always pushed forward.
The ear became inflamed and the woman
became was suffering much
She noticed the Dotair Ban (Dr
Alexander Macleod passing and
she ran out to meet him and
described her condition. He put
a large dose of snuff on his
dearna – palm and requested her
to sniff it all up. She did so
while he took a firm hold of her
nostrils. She sniffed and sniffed and
sniffed again and at last threw the
grain of bere out some five feet away.

Castlebay Barra. Monday 10th June 1901
In tinkers tent ragged in the extreme Man
and wife and four little children – all dirty
and ragged in the extreme and healthy. lean and wife
extremely intelligent and well informed.
She from Lews and he from Assynt.

Cant. Uilleag=Penny Uillig theom
1/- sheadar uilleag = 6d. Gorsan = 4d
Lumb = £1 / Guilbeanach = shoes. Ean
ach meilg = finger ring. Strand ait =
tobacco. Teamban – pipe. Nobaid = bonnet
Sglatach = tea. Meli = Sugar Glomhaib =
old man. Liogach = boy Suailean = child
Beoir = woman wife. Pearstag = daughter
Teideis = bed. Colum = sheep. Tur = fine
Carail = boat. Sgithan = herring. Dag-
ail chain as leis a charail a dh eug
ail a sgitheil. Noide torn Raige = pail
Buagaleir = bowl. Glogaidhean stockings
Ceampin = tent. Furan = bread. Iogan
Butter. Craodaan = eggs. Sguithead
whiskey Sgimtus = daorach. Carn
arachd – Sabaid. Gēithean = Dog
Blainteag = Cow. Giofan = horse. Blain
teag mhil mhín = Calf. Vuauin =
meal. Feathian = flesh. Denceall
an = Eeyes. Bileag = bial stimeagan
teeth sguirdean – neck. Laisgeagan –
ears. Caingeagan = hens. Giofag – sow
Failman = milk. Limas = Fodder
Ganach touir = trews. Bliantail –
shirt. Camag – drawers. Lumbag
blanket. Gannach ga bhagail dha
rathail – something given you
12 men in the Cleir sheanchain

Thoir dhomh righ nan spìnean
sith na h-ath shith agus ional
sgrios airson sgrios nam Peacach

One shopkeeper in Stornoway
gave him salt tobacco and a fine
comb. Fiodh nach eil cam s nach
eil direach = saw dust.

Gramaid = fool. Gramiseag = shefool &c &c
Sguith = water. Càsa = boat. Diorcan =
Tin. Lūigean = feet. Mèilcean – hand
Tulap – body. Toudhar = buttocks. Cleit
ean – cloths. Caidisc guisean = where
do you live? Gomhag Co a tha coistig
a = whos with you

O Na bi gun chu na h {arachtog cuillean
Beannag = breid kertch. Beannag = 3 cornered
Breasaclian = mutches. Osan osanan
footpolyless stocking. Deannadair = hammer
horseBridlebit = mioionach. Na lus si nar bras
Have you taken youyour food. Caran an glamh-
ach sin. Strike that carle. Bag siort
a leagach mhin an gearc geircu
an tainig an giorcan = Falbh
sin a bhalaich feuch an tainig an tin
Glothach canalabaich = Foolish carle
Fualach Inead an tòraich In
Hasten do that. Liadalaich inead
do mhosg = Go clean thy face –
Mo bhratham gun bhras air a chom
gun ghrad a bhagas e = be with
out food to night and I without
money to get it. Talasg = Day. Conn =
night. Nèad an cian = Shut the house.
Noip = peats. Mu naoim = my shame
Treaban – lies. Cara mi noig air
a choim. Sgling – solder Sairc =
cheese. Griugam = curds. Nèad guisean
sit down. Bag i do luigean = Go on thy feet

A woman had a child. Her husband
placed a sheep on the eallag and cut off
her head. He went out and one of his two
boys placed his younger brother on the eallag
and raised the axe to kill him. She rushed
out of bed and killed the infant beside her.
She went mad and went 7 years
with the deer. She used to come to the house
every night and thus she sang.

lg.l: A choillich dhuibh a bhrolbhroillich dhergdhearg
A saoibhiris dhan taigh sam bi do ghuth
Do'n thug mis a chuir na h-oichoidhche
Bidh m ianan fhein gam chumail muigh
Leum a thug mi s an druis
Chomhlaich CxCriosd mi aig mo chas
Chuir e mismise air an rathad mhor
Le ghloir is le mhais
Bhean a thug air iolan. charn
Chuir coin a bhaile uile gam lorg
Dh ol mi bainne do dha chioch
IIs laidh mi 9 misoa na do bholg
Moch sa mhad-mhaduinn dhomh bhi dusgdusgadh
Chunna mi smuir do thaigh na bainnse
Tha mo dhurachdhurachd ri RiRigh na soillse
Gum suas a bhuinigeas brigh na bainnse
Siud tri treothan na do chomhlamh CxCriosd
Taigh na siursach gun choir air clann

choice.expan: Taigh na siursach gun choir air clann

lg.l: Na taigh na h aighil gun duil bhi ann
Suil a thug mi air mo chul
Chunna mi Cro fhreasdail air an stiuir
Peadail Pol as Eòin baistidh
Gamhan gu dludluth san suil ri deas
Dh fhosgail an t athar
Is gheitich am fonn
Sgoilt an fhairge loma ghlas
RiRigh aona mac Dhe thiginnthighinn gu teach
ŏichŏichdhe is ŏichŏichdhe ma tha ruig a side
Is bocbochd dhe na stoc a bhuain iad mi
An t seana chruidh chuilbh bhig
A threig go mo mhios
ŏichŏichdhe is ŏichŏichdhe mo mhios gun bhreig

div.p:
This occudoccured in Garbhath mhor
betwnbetween and Badenoch
The deer were coming to the corn and she among
them. Her mother sent the dogs to them – "iolair
charm". Her husband was going to marry
again and she grieved much but she got
him at last for she came home just
in time. Isabella Macdonald nee
Stewart from the Chisholms. Grand daughter
of Hanna Chisholm and Grandniece to
Isabella Chisholm. Shes a very nice modest well
mannered wife.

Glen, Barra, 12th June 1901
Peggie Macneill wife of Eoin RaoillRaghnaill, Glen Barra

lg.l: Le Moir Iele mac
Le aileanaingealan mo Righ
Gam dhion on gach olc
LaiLaidh mi le D.Dia
Is lailaidh D.Dia liom
Dia agus MorMoire agus MMicheil liom
Cros nan 9 aileanaingealan fionn
O mhulmhullach mo chinn
Gu troieantroighean mo bhonn
Cha lailaidh mise leis an olc
Nar a mu laieaslaidheas an t olc liom
Dia os a bhileas ghloire liom
Mhic na h oigh ura
Saor sinn on na piantan
Tha iosal donlia s duimhe
GuiamGuidheam P.Peadar GuiGuidheam Pol
Guieam Guidheam Moire OOigh sa mhac / an Oigh
Guieam Guidheam an Da Ostal deug
Na reaila an suigra len cead
Nuair a dhealarchas an t ionan / D'uine
Ris na collas claon
Na ghlumaga socair
Am focha na siorruichd
Dia agus Amen

div.p:
The man parts with the soul in
glumags like a person a tilgeol

lg.l: M anamsa an a laimhs a Righ
A Righ na carachchathrach nĕonĕomh
Is a tu bheir a cheanncheannaich e
Micheal geal am comhcomhdhail m anams
A DDhia na fala fir.firinnich
Na diabar mi o mhuintmhuinntireas
A liudliuthad loclochd a rinn mo chorp
Nach fhadfhaod mi nocnochd a chunntuchach
Tha nis a lailaidh nocnochd anns a bhas chadail
Leis a bas cadail dhomh lalatha
MGu mar a dheis lamhs
A dhuisgeas mi
Iosa nan aingeal dean troctrocair orm
Le mhor throcair
O'n naideannamhaidean dian mi o Righ.
O mo Dhia tha ami gam luart
Dhut m anams mo cholancholann

Gu rorobh thu nad mhaighmhaighstir agus nad
cheannard orm.

div.p:
Heard this from her father John Macneill and another when
a child and she has taught to her own
children of ten – mo many of whom
are dead now. Both had many many
old hymns now lost and never heard – not
even the name of them.

Mo Nighean Donn a Cornaig
living in Tiree

He was courting a girl in Coll. Two
other lovers of the girl killed him & she went
out with her fathers kine.
Dualas = droch shiol. Fhailbh = failbe falamh

Gailion MacKinnon was a sailor and was long
astray. He saw in a dream and his fatherfather's
mother came to him and said you are
longing for land. You will see land
at 3 pm the day after tomorrow.
He told this to the mate and at
the time said they saw land
and there was great rejoicing for they lost
their course and all hope. He was
a famous s mariner and very quick
in tongue and act.

Mas corrach gob an dubhan 's farsuin
bial lamh tabh said a stutingstuttering woman

lg.l: Se t eilbheileadh san teilbheileadh
"Se "t-eileadh bu docha leum
Se teileteileadh beag a thoir nan gobhar as a chreig
Bi iad an na buth
A siubhal as an leine
Cia mar a ni mi an obair
S gun an gobha (glas) carach
Sa bhannaich gun suidh
AnAn rud a bh-aig an {t straigeir saighdear
An ru crochadh ris an nighin duibh
A chuile lalathas oichoidhch
An crochadh ris an nighin duibh

One woman in Keantangval who
has frthfrith made lalatha ceanceann a raith
– wonderful pred.prediction she made

Man at Cille bharr saw him
self. He and another were going by
at Allasdal and they saw a torradtorradh
Come aside said he

lg.l: Cnamh do chir chaorchaora lom
Is binn linn na ceol na filefidhlefile
Cnamh do chir chaorchaora lom

div.p:
Breuvaig 13 June 1901 Wednesday
Catl Catriona Macneill cottar
all alone in a poor bothag.

lg.l: A SpSpiorad naomh is mo neart
Thig ionnionnsaigh meas cum rium fo read
Bho thala is ailliaillidh tha s na flath
Do shoills aghoraghmhor deas nar measg
Athair ionmhuinn s gach aon nochd
Bho bheil gach tiolailidtrioblaid is mo feart
Air cricrithe soill le d iochd
S le d iochd dian sinn o gach olc
Gun do dhiadhach cha neil ni
As am duinn chois pris
As t ionas a RigRigh nan Righ
Gun chion chan fhad sinn a bhi
Gu cobhail stu fhear a thann
An aoghaiaoghaidh an anam is milsle cainnt
Ga'ailGabhail s tait a th' ann
Dean tau is treon dhuindhuinn anns gach aum
Laub gach ni tha rag riut fhein
Gach ni tha fuar dean blath fo sgeith
GaGach aon theid seachran ad sligh
Glac a stiuir s cha teid a dhidhith
Gach ni tha truaillidh glan gun dealdail
Gach ni tha cruaicruaidh dean maoth led ghras
Gach creuchd tha deaniu craic
Leigh nan Leigh dean fein e slan
Bheir dha mhuinntmhuinntir bhi gu dian
A cur an earbs ann mar Dhia
Gus an cuideachadh s gach gniamh
Seachd tiodhlac Spiorad nam fial
Dean d shaothreahshaothrach cadal is tamh
D Teas dhan fhionnachd naomh is fhearr
A sholas a bhroin gabh dhuinn cas
Na diult dhuindhuinn an diugh do bhaigh
O sholus is gile na ghrian
Grunnd ar cricridhe lionsa Dhia
Sa mhuinntmhuinntir tha muigh an sliabh
An seachran coimhead air cian
Sa bheathea thoir dhuinn do bhaigh
Bi nar fochas an ann ar bais
Bi nar fochas an ann ar bais
Bi nar fochas an ann ar bais
Amen

div.p:
Is corrach gob an dubhan is mairg gam cuilidh
an cuan

Is taomanach an t iasg
Is saoilinneach an t sealg
Cuir do bhuinigmhuinghinn air an talamh
Fear nach do fhas duinn falamh riamh

Is ann an ceann na seachseachd blianabliadhna
Is dh innseinnseadh an t iasgair iasgach

lg.l: Gad a b'iuih an fhairge ghlas
S gad bu phluim ith ialaidh nam ban
Nan speir cha sgiubh. iad loc

div.p: Said a Barra (cross man)

lg.l: Na fhuair thu grasan a bhi glic
Na bi sgaoilteach an a chuid
Nuair a charar thu fon lic
Cuirear roinn dhith air a shon.

div.p:
Ma fhuair thu eolas air Dia
Bean t anam s t uile ghniamh
Biodh gach ni agad fo dhian
S dhan fhiomach toiseach do thriall

Obair an iasgair obair gun fhiach
sgiamhach sglamhail

Borve 16th June 1901
Mary Cameron sister of John Cameron

p.del:
Gui eag a machair ri Dia ri Moire
Mhath 's gach aon eug mhac no tri
Dia gan sabh Dia cliobh Dia
dh fhuasg.fhuasgail orra. Tha mi g ailt
Dhuibh a Dhe uile chumhachdach
aon naomh Mhor bha riariamh na Oigh
Dia dhean fos s sith ri anam
nam marbh chroitreach gu leir.
Gloir dhan AtAthair glor dhan mhac
glor dh an Mhac IIosa Naomh
Ath is ann th am flath bhi guidhe
airson ar anam san lalatha mun
dheiridh – Failt dhuibh a Mhoire
tha sibh lan dheana gras a Leig
DDia bhi maile

Dia ag lu mhath bhi tiom. oirbh
si ruten rath romhai sgaich taotaobh
os an toir sibh bhu raigh Dia bhi
tiom s gar sabhal. Dia bhi
maille riubh oreit rath se romh
an an t saoghsaoghal san an t saoghsaoghal
bhuan na teirig.

div.p:
Mac De bhi dian s gar geaird rath
is corr all dhuinn iarra dhaibh.
Gach neach tha gam leas. gan
leas Dia anam. Gun dion Dia
riubh air gach tai an toir sibh bhur
agh s gam fosg. Dia gach bial romh.
gach naomh s gach ban naomh tha air
feaths bhi gar air bhur son. Gun
toir tog Dia sinn bho staddstaid a pheac
gar staid nan gras gu Gloir fhlath
dha na h-anam gu leir.

lg.l: A Righ gach ros
Sa chas nach crion
Is ann nad bhuinn
A tha sinn uile
Laieam dle Dia

add.p:
Chan fhacas muir
nach robh torr
cabhaig oirre

lg.l: 'S lailaidh DDia liom
Le chom s le lach
Mo laimh D deise
A dian sa teos am anama
Glansa dhuinn gach uile thrualaid
Leighis an anam
Na treig e sinn an uair ar bais Amen.

div.p:
Murdoch Macdonald Borve whose
wife is daughtdaughter of Alexander Macdonald
wishes to get a croft in Greian Must
help him.
Ceum air ghàig = Against the will

Mor Maclean bean MurdMurdo Maclean long ago from Duart Mull nee Macneil datdaughter of
AlexAlexander Macneil Keantangaval Barra
a woman of fine voice understanding and
and a beautiful singer
div.title: Smaladh An Teine

lg.l: Smal mise nocnochd an teine
Mar a smal CxCriosd an aitheal
Gu ma slan a bhios an tein
Gu ma slan a fhios sinn uile
Aighlean De dh'eisd
Bial DDe a sabhsabhail
Aigheal an dorus mo theighe.
Gu m tig an lalatha geal am mairmaireach
Amen

div.title: An Saibhir Sanntach
div.p:
A lonely weaver woman in Uist was alone
a bruich bonnach sa lion iteachan when
a sub. crofter came home and said -

Is buibuidhe dhus is tu tha socsocair an t saolssaoghalsa
chan ion.ionnan agus mis is iuma rud tha cur
{dragh{rium orm. Chan eil sgath a cur dragh
orms ach mi fhein Gu de chuir dragh
ort agus thu cho math dheth.
Tha curam orm gach oicheoidhche a laidheas
mi agus lalatha dh eirdh eirich mi na bheil agam
ri suil a thoir air agus an saoghal
a fairleachadh orm. Cha neil sgath
curam orms ach mi m anam lalatha no
oicheoidhce ars ise. Nuair a dh fhalbh easan
thois i ris an laoidh nuair a fhuair i
bhi le fhein

lg.l: Is olc an saibsaibhir sanntsanntach
Nach leir dha fhein rud ghanntair
Man theid a cheal teann / an ceo'al teann
Am aum a chur san lai
Nam a chuir sa charnaich
Gum beag a luth tl na thabhaid
IosIosa a Righ nan grasan
Dean thusa favarfabhar ris
Dean caranachd is caoimhneas
Dhan anam nach do thoill e
IosIosa RiRigh na soillse
Gar faoineachd uinne riut
Nuair theid an t suil a dhundhunadh
Sa chiste chaoil nach diult sinn
B fhearB fhearr nach beirt o thus sinn
O bhios an cuirt riut
A chuirt mhor nad fhianuis
Sa sid a dh fhagas shios sinn
Nan fithich dhuibh gu sior
Be sid an iamhaidh dhubh
Be sid an iamhiamhaidh granaghrannda
Gun eirechdaseireachdas gun ailleas
Iosa RiRigh nan grasan
Dean thusa favarfabhar ris
Tha t fhuil a falbh na h alltain
Is tair ansanns gach lamh dhiot
Bu truagh an tuisge bh annta
An ann a bhi gan cuir
Nach smoinsmaoin iad do chruadal
Feas fala an a ghruaimean
S na h Iubhaich dol mu ghuail dhut
Le cu mair gun iociochd
Nach d sheall iad an ad aodaodann
Stu AthAthair sluagh an t saoilsaoghail
Na dh fhalbh s na thig a dhaoin
Tha am fiamh san aogasg riut
Nach d sheall iad an ad aodaodann
Stu AthAthair sluagh an t saoilsaoghail
Na dh fhalbh s na thig a dhaoin
Tha am fiamh san aogasg riut
Dh ord.Dh ordaich iad ein aintoil
Nach eud eireeireadh tu gun taing dhaibh
Gum faigh iad an t-am
An a cheanis. gu goirt
An t iar a bha sa bhanntail
Gun dh eirich gun taing dhaibh
S gur ghann e air an t slabh.slabhruidh
Le samhla RiRigh nam feart

div.p:
They put a cockcockerel on the fire in a pot
Feuch nach eir CxCriosd ors a fear
Cha n eirich gun goil an coilecoileach tha
sa phoit air an teine ga bhruich
orsa fear eileile. Leum an coil.coileach as a phoit
agus bhuail e dha sgath air an
t slamhruidhslabhruidh. Sheall iad far an
thiolthiodhlaich CxCriosd agus fhuair an uaigh
falamh fas.

Bha piuapiuthar C-cilleChalum-chille agus ban nanabuidh
dol gu airairidh AbarAbair thus as C.Calum-cille gur
mulmulachaig na h airiairidh a tha agad air do
mhuin.

Sgoiltidh am farmad a chlach –
Bha piuthar Chalumchille agus boireannach eile
falbh thun na h-airidh. Cuir clar na brath
ann am plāt air do mhuin agus d uair
a dh'fheorricheasdh'fheoraicheas do bhan-nabuidh dhiot
de tha agad sa phlàt abair thus gu bheil
a mhulachag airidh.

When CxCriosd was being crucifcruicified a smith was
asked to make nails to nail his hands
and feet to the cross. The smith refused
and then a t ceard was asked and hence
the ordering of tinkers all over the world

If 9 nine nines of heads are taken
off the daoldaolag a boy will not go
to the aite s miosa with teeth. This
was done by boys in Barra

The story of the killing of the wren
after the Boyne – his tapping with the
bill on the drum of the ProtestProtestants
and waking them. Killed evyevery whewhere
by Catholics

A bit of the bian of the dobhar
chu saves the owner in battle.
The doardobhar chu can only be Killed
thro the ball geal fon spogan
The dobhar chu sis righ nan
biasta dubha – always 7 ottars
along with

If a man puts his tongue on gruthan na
beiste duibhe he has healing if a
person gets burnt he puts his tongue on
the burn it never rises – and the burn
heals quickly

A baile in Tiree never crow of cock
Calum cille was going from his fols
and thought he would pass through
before the cock crew. While passing
through the cock crew. He crossed
the town and left a fagail that no
cock would ever crow there again
and no cock crows there.

The liabag saw Calum gille
passing and Calum gille ceann lialiath
Ma tha ceann lialiath orm biall cam
biodh ortsa tso and hence ceann
bial cam na liabaig.

The maidenmaighdean mhara is seen the man
who sees her ought to tell his comcompanions in the
boat But he should give a nasga
du deire because its she is a bad
comhlaiche and ought to be propitiated

A lobster crew in Pabay saw the
each mara in Sloc Lanruige geo
The youngest of the crew swooned – He
rose three times. The horse looked
like a two year old colt or lothaith. The
main mung was short, the head
was shapely – // Probably this was the
walrus – not unknown on the west
coast // Walrus?

Luirgneachan – that part of the tether next
the foot. Gearraiste the part next the
ciopain the udalan between.

In Ireland in Connaught was is the
baile where the cock does not crow.
Christ was asked where he was going
and he said the not till the cock
crew. They placed all the cocks
under cumain agus poitean so that
that they would not crow. They
have never crowed since. They
were not so cursed in our Highlands
and islands as all that – not in Tiree.
In

Calum cill was going along in his
bgiorne – a hollow tree – when
his biorne struck a rock – mhollaich
e an sgeir gun chaileach dhean
feuran do dhuin no do bheothabheothach
fas oirre gu brath tuilltuilleadh
agus cha d fhas bho n lalatha sin. Thug
mollacagmollachdag air an sgeir Tha i dubh
cruaidh ann a sid.

C-CilleCalum-Cille had all kinds of trades in AoiIdhe
– tailtailors shoeshoemakers saoir smiths and luchd
tin. Cha rorobh feum sam bith air tean
achair – bheireadh iad an iaraniarann
dhearg nan laimh. gus na pheac.pheacaich
iad fhein.

A smith went across to Mull and
saw a beautiful woman after a
cow - When he came home he said that
it would be well for themselves to
have a cow - Far am bi bo bith
bean far am bi bean bith buirbuireadh
said C C.Calum Cille. But the cow was got and
the woman followed. Then peac
gin began and then the smith no
longer could hold the hot iron.

One of his servtservants said C. CCalum Cille's mother
that C.CCalum Cille was not so holy as he prepretended
Is he not said the mother. She went
to bed – Gu de tha oirbh osC-Calum Cille tha mi
bocbochd – Gu ma seacseachd tinneas oirbh a
mairmaireach. Bha sin fuasachfuathasach bocbochd An
lalatha na mhairmhaireach - thainig C CCalum Cille staigh
as thuirt e ri mhathair CiamCiamar
tha sibh a mhathmhathair. Tha sin nas fhearfhearr
ors ise. Tha ors easan ciod thuig thuirt
sibh rim fan rorobh sibh tinneas s gun sibh
a bhi tinn idir – Gum bu seacseachd fearrfhearr
a bhios oirbh mairmaireach - She grew better
at once. Then they all knew that
C-CCalum Cille was a holy man.

When C cilleCalum cille came from EirnEirinn to Albann
he built a church in Uist. He went to the top
of the church and could see EEirinn from it.
He pulled it down again. Then
he went to Skye and built a church
but could not see EEirinn AoiIdhe and Skye
were the only two places from which
he could not see Eirinn.

Prod, Grăidh = Hoise {Flataig {Sgithan = haing Pioban
whisky. Smoulan – Potatoes. Geanach
beoir = bean. Glomhach noid = man
Nobaid, eannach – neacain = cap. Is Ean
nach toubhair = trews. Guilbeanach
luigean strons = shoes. Ochlibh-
eanan sodanan = stocksingsstockings Cruinneas
eagan. Potatoes. Bleantabh – shirts
Topach turran su bannoch. Niaumh
uin = meal. Togan Iongan – butter
Geali – sguar. Sguithead = whisky
Glomhach agus an canlubach air – Man
inis tipsy.

When they were after CxCriosd the daoldaolag
said an de chaichaidh Mac De seachad
The cearrlomanceardaman put his foot in her
mouth and although she tried to speak
she could not

An Esganan ThogThogadh an sgadan a checheann
as a mhuir agus thuirt e Is mismise righ
na mara. CaCaite an d fhag thu mise
ors an liabag a cur car na bial,
a magadh air. The car cam
remained in his mouth ever after.

A trusg was caught at Diabaig
in Torasdan 18 inches long.
A red tape was tied round the tail.
It was caught on the East coast
next season. This was the King of
the trusgs

Ciosmal built about
1440 or thereby, by an earl of Bute
for his daughter married to a Macneill of Barra

Tha'n cia sa bheinn tha'n ceo s a bheinn 's air an leacainn
Tha'n ceo sa bheinn s air a ghleann
D uair thachair orm an fheanndach ghasta fionndach = fionn fionnag a fair woman

lg.l: FalbhFalbh lom is thug falamh molach
S beir am boirboirreanach BeallBealltain
Bho'n a d fhag uthu an rusg so
Fag rusg eile

div.p:
Aon gu Mart fas
Mart gu gearradh

The man will cut a handful glac
on bheart lest it should be too ripe be
fore the next Mart The man took off his
bonnet on seeing the new // If an east coast man sees a breac or bradan coming
in with the net she shakes his head omi
nously as bad luck.

Friday will is the day for cutting the harvharvest
in MiulayMingulay. The first corn sown is
consecrated with holy water.

The water brotbrought in at night – a dileag
is thrown into the fire as a b libation to the
fire god

Sgiobal = barn, especially barn
where tithes are collected, as sgiobal skŭbo
in Sutherland once the seat of the bishop

lg.l: GaoGaoth an iar airear a Challaig
FuacFuachd is feannadh
GaoGaoth a deas a Challaig
Teas is torradh

div.p:
Eirigeach = Heretic – A woman in MiulayMingulay
was so holy she would not drink out of
the same vessel with a ProtProtestant. She was
a great thief. & lies.

Slan far an innseas when a man
dies. naodh naodh anan

The root of the Eala bhuibhuidh is eaten
for its sweetness

Leaideag taobh to Orasay dheth an
Bhadh at Castlebay.

The LangaiLangaid has a siolag in his bill
and only one which she gives her isean
The peata ruaruadh has a dozen in his
bill. The Duiearach the same as the
peata rruaruadh.

lg.l: Mas a gaogaoth an ear a ChallChallaig
Teas is tomadh Meas air chrannuibhdh
Mas a gaogaoth a tuatuath a CChallaig
FuacFuachd is feannadh
Mas a gaogaoth a deas a ChChallaig
Teas is torradh
Mas a gaogaoth an iar CChallaig
Iasg is aran
De ghaoth a dh fhag a Challaig?
Di sathuthairne sanntach
Di Lauin Di Luainmall cinnteach
Dithaoin gu fas
Di mairt gu gearradh

DuarDuair bhios crannalaich do ghaoith an
ear –
GaoGaothan ear on o'n Challaig
Fuadach eisg on charraig
Call carcaraid taghtaghal tric
Call car.caraid taghtaghal aineamhainneamh
S call carcaraid gun a thaghthaghal t idir / tric no ainmig

div.p:
Limalaich = Tea substance. Quote
solidersoldier. Chuir Dhoirt mi mi mach an
limalaich.
Cladh Chaluim chille in Miuthlaidh

LaLatha Brianan the man went to plough
this day in a lag beag and he became.

The man in Bailechaolas in Vat
tersay. – The day was wild and he said
Cumaidh sinn LaLatha fheill Padruig an
diugh agus ni obair am maireahmaireach. In
the morning it was pitch dark. At last
a man got up seacseachd sgith cadail
The house was buried in snow

lg.l: Dhia bean.beannaich mi
Chuala Padruig DomhDomhnull dubh
Is miosmiosa an lalatha 'n diugh nan de
Ga mor a shios is a ni
Is beag am pios an taigh mhic De.

div.p:
"Cha'n fhaiceadh Brianan e." Pioba dheth.
The place was so hidden. Thugadh dhach
aidh dall.

Bha i ranaich Tha eagal gun eiridh
s e cho trom ann an luchd seirbhseirbhis

Goimhseagan. Their brother was possdpossessed
hence their madness. Catriona and Mor
were the names of the goiseagangoimhseagan.

Teannachadh = Sustenance
Daibil = Doubt. Tha daibil agam
ann I have a doubt in it
Dubh-chapail = Lies

div.title: Luideag na h-aibhne -
div.p:
Met a man and he tied her in front of his
house. He brotbrought her home. Leig as mi is gheobh
thu t iarratas in (Gearrloch). Cha leig mi
Thug e dhachaidhachaidh i as cheathalcheangail e i sa chul
taigh. Fhuair i mu sgaoil. agus dh eubh i san
uinguinneig Duair is aird thu s ann is isle thu
D uair is isle is ann is ard thu agus so
thuit sin fo nach do leig thus mis as
d uair a dh iarr mi ost. &c. &c. &c.

Rinneadh connalach dh an
sgoth air a cham Chollach.

Faileim = Pot lid. Mŏta mod e
= suadh e sua e = in making porridge.

Old men say that the son raven kills the
father raven. Calum MacPhie MiulayMingulay
says that he and other men leading horses to the peats
Two ravens all morning were fighting up in
the air. One raven fell down dead at
their feet. The smell from it was aw-
ful

Mola-mhogan – miolamhag muile
mhag – murra-mhagag = Frog
Fuil cirein coillich will put away warts.

The soul goes away as a dove – If a dove sis seen
about the house of a dying person the sign
is good – CXChriosd as a dove. The raven is bad seun
when a person is about to die – or the rook.
Ian bais. a small curlew. predicts
death. like the sand piper – gives a sharp pipe
or sgreal

Glug a bhas = In Barra a bird that comes near the house
the at night before a death

Fatadh = Hospitality. as Fataidh am bleidire
agus bithidh e oichoidhche agad.

In going to the carraig the man
would call to his neighbours –

lg.l: Eimh iuch iuch
S a mhuir air chrith
s an t iasg na ruith
San t ian dubh ag eubhach
O fuil is farra-dheargaibh
'S ann dearg an na shul a muigh

An lon agus barr dearg air
fuil an eisg

div.title: Luideag na h aibhne
div.p:
rud gu luidreadh san ruibh
Bha bean a muigh san chrodh
san oichoidhche – madinmaduinn mhoch mhuc
agus chunchunnaig luideag bheag bheag a
nigheadh leine – De Ruig e
orra De tha thu deandeanamh a sin

lg.l:
Tha leine da Ruarai agus
leine t aona mhic sa cuideachd.
An e an leine chein
San leine bhuain mi
An leine chir sa chlobh
Sa chard mi
Sa sul shniamh mo lamh
Sa dh fhigh mi fhin
Sa chaillachchailleach bheag nan tri iongh
As ionaghanadh liom
De chuir a sin thu
Tha feum agads air a sin
Thig do mhacsa agu ach cha tig da Ruairi

div.p:
Leig i as a chailleachag
Bhathadh do Ruari an a
Cham Chollach ach shnamh
mac na banntrach gu tir.
This was in Tangastal Barra
Da Ruairi two brothers

Balach a bha g ith diasan
seagail – Thuirt an duine bhalbhalaich seach
aig Bochd

lg.l: Nach tu anam biastach
Gu ith nan diasan
An ta am Fios a chiuthamh nan diasan
Gun toir e asadsa na fiaclan
Mun tig ceann na bliadhna

div.p:
Thog an duine sin leis an gill dha
na h Arcamh agus tha a riamh
ann a sin chon an lalatha n diugh.
'S e bocbochd thangastail a thug iad
air

Nialadaireach – seeing in the
sky the progprogess of death

A man at Tangastal had an only
son. The man was well off and he
and his wife and daughters were so
good to the son that he grew up very
big and strong and handsome. The
whole family were proud of the young
man. The young man was just 20.
The father and the son were out on
the cnoc when a little old man
appeared beside them cha robh fhios
bho Dhia co as a thainig no co an
taobh – Se so do mhacsa – Is e thaltha
gille briagh barail foghainteail agad a so. Tha ach
fliuch do shuil a bhodaich gun
bheannachaidh. Mun tig ceann
lalatha s bliadhna bithidh am foid tha fo
chas na cluasaig fo cheann. A bhodaich
an diabhuil gu de tha
thu ag rath agus chuir mach a lamh
gu beirsin air an duine gu crath
adh a thoir air. Thainig nial a
nuas agus cha robh an ath shealladh
aig an tuathanach dhan dhuine
Fhuair Gilleothan am spaid agus
ghearr e am fod a bha fo bhidein
a ghill agus thilg e mach air
a mhuir e.
LaLatha briadh teith samhraidh bha mac
Ghilleothanain agus gille og eile
dam fairgeadh fhein shios aig
Airdbhuridh agus a feachain co
b fhearr a shnamhadh agus a
b fhaide dh'fhearreadh fotha –
Cha d eirich mac Ghilleothain
agus ruith na gillean gu dach-
aidh a dh'innse dha. Thruis
muinntir a bhaile agus an ceann
ochd lalatha fhuair athair a mhac
agus am fod na cluasaig fo cheann.

lg.l: An e an leine a chuir mi
'S an leine bhuain mi
An e an leine chir chlobh mi
'S a leine chlobh sa chirshuath mi
'S an leine lin a shniamh mi
S a dh'fhigh mo dha lamhan fhein

Sa chailleach bheag nan
Tri ioghnadh
Is ionaghnadh liom fhein
Gu De chuir a sinseo thu.

div.p:
Barra People were
gu modhail narach mochaireachmochaireachd cosanda cosandsa
mar nach eil iad an diugh.
Said an old man

Connalaich = Firewood, broken wood
Rèim = Rim as of a wheel
Com, cloth folded on a board
Suthail = subside
Ruilich = search. Spràig = Broken
things, smodal, wreckage.

An Lēig – the lakelet below Loch Tang
astal. running from Loch tangasleLoch tangastal to
the sea is Abhuinn Bhan.
Luisteadh leine. Abhuinn nam
breac comes into Loch tangastal from the
west

Sgoiltidh am farmad a chlach – Envy
will rend the stone.

D'uar bha piuthar Chalum chille
agus a ban-nabuidh falbh thun na h airidh thuirt C. cilleCalum cille
ra phiuthar. D uair a dh fheoir-
icheas do bhan-nabuidh dhu Bheir leat a clar na bhrath ann am plat
agus d uair a dh fheoraicheas do bhan
nabuidh dhiot de that agad a sin
abair/their thus gu bheil mulachag
na h-airidh. Is ann mar so a bha.
D-uair dh-fhalbh na mnathan chun
na h-airidh, thuirt a ban nabuidh
ri piuthar Chalum chille – De tha
agad sa phlat air a mhuin? Tha mul-
achag na h-airidh. A Mhoire sa Mhic
bi mhulachag mhor i. Cha b ionnan
is mise nach bi do bhainn aig no sud
bho nach dean mulachag bheag gun
ghuth air mhulachag mhor. Thug a bhrath
spreathadh aiste agus bha
i na mile mire anns a phlat air
druim a bhoirionnaich!

Danes danced in the Island of Eigg.
Orsa Nighean a Mhuillear
A Bheist Dubh.

Fathaman = Fabhan = Light breeze
Fanadh = Gentle rowing when fishing rods.

Mrs MacDonald Mc Paul (MacPhail)
Smith Place Leith P Walk
173 Leith Walk

lg.l: S e Macgillemhicheil a rinn mi chuid fhin a
S e "Macgillemhicheil a rinn mo thudanalbho bhas

div.title: LaoiLaoidh Dhughail Thaillear (Liosdair?)
div.p:
Ann Macdonald, Achadoire Gleann SpeanLoch
aber 75 years of age 23 July 1901 / Tuesday

lg.l: Cuimhnich a dhuine s bi t fhiacail
MadMaduinn na t aisirigh taruinn dludluth dhut /
Eisd an trombtrombaid fhoirthoir an aire
Guth nan aingilaingeal thig a d t ionionnsuigh / dhusgadh.
Ga soc.socair thu ann do leab.leabaidh
CuimhCuimhnich gur aithghairrde an uair
Mu tha curam agad dheth t anam / dhut
Greas ort Eirich gu h ealamh s dian is gabh t-urnaigh
Cha n'i uighuirnigh ghoirid fhionfhionnar
CuimhCuimhnich a dhuine ri cuis duit
Bheir an uingh.uirnigh ni dhut buinigbuinneag
Ort gun guilguille thu an do fhuilin
Cha do chuinchuimhnich riamh do shalairfhalcair
A dh or no dh airgairgead no dh iontash
Na ghaarghabhair eirig t anaman
Greis oirt gun dearmad s dean t urnrigh
Mu ni thu ri le creideamh
Cha n eil teagteagamh dhuit an eisdeisdeachd / Cha deifir
Rug le durachd so an luchd teagasg
Thoir fuasdal nach dean thu eucair
CuimhCuimhnich air do bhoid.bhoidean baistbaiste
Gur iad sin faodadh dan geil thu
Mun treig thu rathad a pheacpheacaidh
Glacan Glaisean an ion.ionad na pein thu /
Gu ion.ionadion na pein a sheach.sheachnadh
Gu Bi gu faicleach an do ghiulan
Cum na faineanfaithntean s treig gach cleachdadh
Ris an rorobh am peacpeacadh gad lubadh
CuimhCuimhnich gach blianbliadhna chaichaidh seachdseachad
Gur adharaobhar arteul is tursa
Smaoinsmaointeachadh air gach cuis mar thach.thachair
Thu bhi peacpeacadh le durachd
Ach cum nach striocstriochd tu don riaghait
Le do lab.labhairt briarach breugach
S mor a chuis eagal Dia dhut
D uair theid t fhiachfhiachan an a bhiulaobh
Gach aon ni chum e mad chomhair
Dhuilt thu riamh a dheandheanamh
Anns gach gniamh a ni droch sgeul ort
Ach bi CxCriosd air cathar a cheartas
Diolaris gach neach mar bha i
Bha toir da spud is masladh
Bithidh e le talcais gan aich.aicheadh
GheoGheobh lamh dheas ordun gluasad
S a bhi tartarruing suas gu farrais
Bheir flathflathanas mar dhuais daibh.
S cluinnear guth an uan ag rathain
A mhuinmhuinntir sin a rinn an ceartceartas
Tual.Tuathal a sliabh gun arois
Don rioghrioghachd sin a dh-ord Dia dhuibh
Far am bi sibh gu dilindilinn sabhailt
An lamh thoisgeul bho nach fhiach i
Sguirar i le riasladh grainelgraineal
Mar a bha e g innsinnse riamh dhaibh
LiuarLiubhrar i le Dia do Shatan
Bith iad an ironifrinn gam pianadh
Losgadh gach ial s nach cnamh iad
Sgreadail is diosgandiosganaich fhiacal
Gun solus gun soillse nam fardrach
Nis builbuillichidh gu diaghaidiaidhigh
An fhiughal tha gur triall den lai'eanlaithean
Gluais an an solus ChChriosd
Co fad s a ni ghrian oirbh dears.dearrsadh
Bhoin se fhin a phaigh na fiachan
Na dichuimhdiochuimhnich a chaideaschairdeas
Mun tig e dh-ifrinn sios sibh
BeanBeannachd Dia dhuibh s tion.tionnadaidh trath ris
Fhir tha d sheas.sheasamh air mo lic
Bha mise mar tha thusthusa an trasd
S e mo leableabaidh an diugh an uaigh
Cha n eil smear no smuais am chnamh
Gad tha thusa laid.laidir og
Cha mhair thu beo gad ghuair thu dail
Se mo chomhairlcomhairle dhut bi glic
CuimhChuimhnich tu gun tig am bas
Gach aon a chailleadh i an-uair
Na ri annrathanradh truagh a chuain
Gu siol fhaighean theid iad suas.
A dh'fhad.dh'fhaodainn buaibuaidh le fuil an uain
GheoGheobh iad buaibuaidh mar fhuair an siol
ChaiChaidh lionarlionmhar anns an fhonn
Cuid de dh fhas gu fallain direach
S cuid na charran iosal crom / lom
S aig an Buain a chuid a bhios lionar
S am bi brigh is torradhtoradh trom
Fagar a chuid a bhios eutrom
S ligearleigear leis a ghaoighaoith am moll

div.title: LaiLaighidh mise le Moire 's le m Mac
div.p:
(Tha e air ag rathradh an neach their an
laoilaoidh so le durachd naa chuil oicheoidhche
nach faic e leac iutharna gu siorruisiorruidh).

lg.l: Le MathMathair mo Righ
Gam dhion bhon olc / lochd
Cha lailaigh mise leis an olc
Cha lailaigh an t-olc lium
LaiLaighu mise a sios le Dia
LaiLaighidh Dia lium / Is lailaigh i Dia nan dia a sios lioin
Dia is Moire {saMac
Gun robh a nochd a laigh lium
Bho mhulmhullach mo chinn
Gu traighean mo bhonn
GuieamGuidheam PeadPeadair guiguidheam o Pol
Gui.Guidheam an da obstal dheug
Gun mise dhol eug a nocnochd
Mhic na h OighOighe curaiOighecubhraidh
Bho'n tu cheanncheannaich sin gu daor

D'uair a dh'fhalbh an t anam
as a cholan
Gun rorobh mis a triall gu Dia
Chruthaich Dia an duine an tus.
Is gearr gus am bi cholan sin seo.
Duisg a dhuin as do chadal.
ChruthChruthaich Dia an duin an tus
Gu staid bhean nan gras
Gun chuir Adhamh sin air chul
D uair thoill e dhuinn anam peapeacadh bais
Duair a bhuain a bhean anam mios
Thug i dh Ah.Adhamh e ri bhlas.
Faint.anFaithntean De gun rinn i bhrist
Thuit e am peacpeacadh is dh-eug i n cais
Dhia chruthchruthaich an saoghal
A ghleadhghleidheadh i i Ah.Adhamh sa gardhgaradh
An duinduine sin ri tightighinn ri t aodanaodann
Dhibhiul aod.aodaich ghabh e naire
Lomanachd a chruth tightighinn a d' fhianais
A Mhic De sann liom is dana
Labhur CxCriosd on se b fhiosrach
Adh.Adhamh rinn na bhrist thu an àineàithne
ThaghThaghadh thu an t annspiordannspiorad nach tus
PrionsPrionnsa an fhir sin nach rorobh ceart
Fhir a dh-orduich grian is solus
Is mor an gaol a thug thu 'n anam
Chuir thu do Mhac an rioghd duinn / riochd
Le fhuil fhir a rinn air clan
Thaine tu oirnn an staoid dhileas
G Dh-fhaotDh-fhaotainn an sith bho thain
Cha do chaomhain thu t fhuil phriseil
Thaom thu sios i chun ar gleidheadh (lair)
Thug iad gleanntreon ort mar naigh
Leat chuir iad an t sleagh
Chuir iad tar.tarragan an d shlios
Bho chrun do chuir gad dha chois
Chionn s gun d-innis thu an fhirinn
ChChriosd chuir iad thu gu bas
SoillSoillse ri anam a Righ nan righ
S dh-eirdh-eirich thu ristrithist an treastreasamh lalatha
Thug thu shuil don fheafheadhainn dhall
Thug thu luths don chripleach thruagh
Thug thu claistclaistneachd fheafheadhainn bhodhar
S thog thu am marbh a bha an aird} san uaidh
Air sliabh Sioin theid an tearbhadh
Mar phrasgan chaorach a gobhnadh
Luchd nam beann dol an ordugh
Sluagh curst air thug na dorinn
Luchd mi-ruin is ruidir us breige
Mor Murt is briste posaidh
Sin ar lalatha bhios deirbh dunadh
DuarDuair theid CxCriosda air bhith na corach
Seall CxCriosd air a lamh thoisgeil
S their e ris an t seorsa chrusta
Ga adhadhradh a dh imir ga'n losgadh
